review_title: President is a Micromanager.  Acts like  Dean, but not a President
pros:
Social Justice Mission
Excellent School
Great benefits
cons:
The President micromanages - and doesn't trust his employees to make decisions. He is involved with detailed decisions within departments. Ugh! 
 He shows a lack of respect for staff internally. Before I left, I heard he discussed disparagingly about Seattle University employees with outside community stakeholders. This was directly from the individual he talked to - not hearsay. No respect for those who have built the University. I decided to leave as a result.

job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Seattle, WA

cons: Classism, not the most LGBTQIA+ friendly (esp if you are trans... expect to be deadnamed and misgendered), managers who have 0 training in management, really bad pay considering the cost of living, people in decision-making positions not listening, lack of communication, being expected to do the work of 3 people.

review_title: Good Learning Experience for group fitness instruction
job_title: Group Fitness Instructor in Seattle, WA
pros: Receive training for group fitness instruction and there is some freedom for class planning depending on the format on your class. Training is set at the pace you are comfortable with. You are able to develop your skills as an instructor in a safe and welcoming environment.
cons: Not compensated for prep time yet still paid Seattle minimum wage. Training is treated more like a class with homework rather than onboarding. Working here feels like a student rather than a professional. Certification cost is out of pocket.

review_title: A disappointing end to a promising start.
job_title: Public Safety Officer in Seattle, WA
pros:
Pros: 

1.) Time off accrued is decent.
2.) Medical benefits are among some of the best.
3.) Education benefits for being a University Employee 
4.) Rotating schedule ensures everyone will get a weekend off.
5.) Actual working schedule typically consists of four days on, with three days off.
6.) Being able to help students in their time of need.
7.) Good exposure to investigatory procedures and complex report writing.
8.) Decent upwards mobility and introduction into supervisory experience.
cons:
Cons:

1.) Wage for the actual job performed.
2.) Lack of training.
3.) No clear communication / conflicting directives.
4.) Injured workers are entitled to nothing / receive no support or backing by the university's mission statement.
5.) Floating holiday hours are and have been taken away from employees of DPS, where other departments receive those hours.
6.) Lack of professional equipment (80% of my equipment is my own)
7.) Sick time usage and being rephermanded or terminated for it's usage. 
8.) University community is at times hostile to DPS, despite being them requesting assistance for DPS services.
9.) Unionization is regularly met with "union buster" meetings and methods. The university has worked hard to keep adjunct faculty in a non-unionized status to take advantage of them and the same methods are used on DPS staff.
10.) University has halted wage increases, despite the job becoming more dangerous and arduous.

job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros: The people I work with directly are great, but the university it set up in such a way that the staff are continuously disrespected. In order to get a raise/title change, you need to rely on your supervisor to do all the advocating for you, and depending on your relationship, that's not always going to happen. Academic staff are frequently and consistently left off important committees, even when the decisions that come out of said committees directly impact them. We are grossly underpaid (there are some Graduate Assistants that make more than staff with Master's degrees), and the process for reclassifying your position--which is the only way to get more than a 2% raise--is extremely opaque.
cons: Again, the people I work with directly are great. I have a ton of flexibility with my hours and working from home when needed. The students I work with a amazing.

review_title: Great Place to Work if Money isn't Important
pros: Seattle University offers many soul-feeding employee opportunities from educational presentations to local and international volunteer opportunities to groups providing education and fellowship, to tuition remission for employees and their children to tuition exchange with other universities an more. The large majority of employees truly support the university's Jesuit mission.
cons: Unless you are in a top leadership position, pay is LOW. The university does periodic reviews of comparative salaries with other local organizations, but I would love to know which organizations they look at and what year they are comparing with.

pros: Good benefits if you qualify with 4 classes.  University affiliation.
cons: Pay is below industry standard (in Arts and Sciences), especially given the high cost of living in Seattle. If you can use this job as an adjunct to your life, it works, but does not provide the income necessary to live from. Given the hours needed to prepare for classes, respond to students and hold office hours, grade, etc, the pay is basically minimum wage for adjuncts. Adjuncts are not always given the resources they need to do their job (office space, equipment). The President of the university recently prevailed in his years long battle to bust union organization of the adjunct and contingent faculty. You are at the mercy of the chair of your department and college dean--conditions vary arbitrarily with this.

review_title: Great place to work if you are a manager but not so great if you are being managed....or lack thereof
pros: Decent benefits, social justice and community focused, get off early on Friday's during the summer, beautiful campus.
cons: Leadership is seriously lacking.  If you are entry level or one step up from entry level, they do not particularly care if you like your job, or if you have issue with others at your work place, as HR seems to have a bit of a hidden agenda to protect Directors, Assistant Dr. and managers. The University's values are amazing, but they do not seem to have people who work in alignment with those values.

pros: Very flexible working schedule. My boss was ver accommodating and wanted me to put my studies first. I was given a fair amount of responsibility and gained a lot of hard skills. If you're looking for an easy job that can help you get a job in an office SU has a lot of work study opportunities. It was worth it for me because I had excellent references after I left.
cons: Some of the work is boring or busy work. Sometimes you will end up redoing projects (when event dates change or something). Other than that, I really enjoyed my time there.

review_title: Be Careful: It all depends on which department you land in.
pros:
-Get the week between Christmas and New Year's off of work
-Get Good Friday and Easter Monday off of work
-Tuition remission
-Great Transportation program
-Students are great!
-Faculty are very knowledgeable and loved by students
cons:
-Human Resources is a mess and no one seems to know which end up is up when it comes to their own handbook and policies
-VERY paternalistic and sexist culture (Essentially it's a Catholic school stuck in the 70's)
-Your success depends on the department that you end up working for. Some departments are just set up to fail and take down all the staff within them.
-It's a revolving door. Someone is ALWAYS LEAVING and the entire school never seems to be fully staffed.
-Salaries are LOW and there are no ways to change jobs, move up, get title changes, get salary increases. It's basically a dead-end job.
-You are expected to work around the clock as "service to Seattle U"
-Supervisors are deadwood and two-faced and will throw you under the bus to save themselves.

-

review_title: Good culture in department, but problems with administration
job_title: Adjunct Professor of Mathematics in Seattle, WA
pros: I worked with great people in the math department.  Good culture and friendly community.  I lucked out and met the minimum requirements to get benefits (teaching for three consecutive quarters, with total hours adding up to at least half time to get health care). The math department wanted to keep me on for another year, but I decided I didn't want a career in teaching.
cons: The administration was making it hard on departments by pressuring them to use adjuncts as contract workers with no benefits.  They originally wanted to hire more than one person to teach the four classes I was hired for, so that they wouldn't have to pay benefits to the adjuncts.  I lucked out because they couldn't find anyone else to split the workload.  It might be better now because SEIU was in the process of organizing adjuncts to form a union.

review_title: Good folks, good benefits, but hierarchical and hardnosed under the feel-good exterior.
pros: Lots of ethical, dedicated, smart people. Generally a good student body overall. True commitment to undergraduate education. Intellectually rigorous, ethically sound, progressive and inclusive environment, even though it's a religious school. Beautiful campus. Far better pay than community colleges.
cons: While most students are serious about their schooling, there is no shortage of entitled, spoiled brats in the student body. This private university also balances its budget on the backs of adjunct employees, just like public schools do. Despite the feel-good image, there is a strong hierarchy and some hardnosed business in the culture--it'd be better to be more upfront about this sometimes.

pros:
The people at SU are very mission driven and strive to create an environment of  shared values. Everyone is working to increase educational opportunities, and to better ourselves and the world. There isn't the normal individual battle for success, rather we believe in helping the community to help ourselves. 

Some other Pros are:
- Great benefits including FREE tuition for full time employees (and dependents)
- Generous vacation time including a week for Christmas. 
- Maternity, Paternity and new family leave
cons: Your work environment and pay are dependent on which department you end up in. Some of the smaller departments face larger office struggles and have difficulties evolving.

job_title: Server Engineer Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros: It depends on what part of OIT you are in. If you are in classroom support, the pros would be a lot of down time with a bunch of other people talking about whatever. You get paid for that. If you are in the back data center working as a Server or Network Assistant, you'll be learning a lot! Since I go to school there as well, my supervisor gives me leeway on work hours.
cons: For the Server Assistant, the cons would be the remote customer service portion if you either don't like talking to people or don't know much about Servers yet. It can be tough calling an angry person to ask them what their problem is.

pros: Amazing city, parks, public  transportation, events, restaurants.  It is a city with many neighborhoods which are truly small towns, so if you dont like one area, you can move to another city.  Really love the French bakeries in town.
cons: Rain, gray weather....  It is difficult for Texans to survive the gray skies and the wetness.  Also, rents are so very expensive, and although there is a lot to do, it is difficult to afford this city.

pros: Generous staff benefits, early Friday release in summer, lots of University holidays, good vacation and sick leave. College staff performed as a great team and was very supportive, there was always someone willing to help out.
cons: Administration is made up of faculty and they're not necessarily considerate of staff opinions, suggestions, views and concerns, tending to lean much more heavily to faculty concerns. Some faculty shunt their work off on to administrative support staff, especially in areas of prospective students. College culture was pretty strained and factions existed between administration, faculty and staff.

review_title: Generally good experience, with some student employment complaints
pros: Flexible hours, works with school schedule, good pay for the hours and for students
cons: can only work 20 hours per week,

pros: Seattle University has an inspiring mission and purpose (educating leaders for a just and humane world); many interesting, committed people doing meaningful work; a tuition benefit for employees after 3 months, and for children of employees after 3 years; 37.5 hour work week; beautiful campus; central location.
cons: Management is top heavy; culture is patriarchal and often secretive. Many departments are understaffed, which means heavy workloads and reactive, rather than thoughtful, decision-making. Both salaried and non-salaried employees work overtime. Policies aren't applied consistently.

pros: Campus focusing on social justice, diversity, and leadership; being on a small campus (~50 acres) makes it easy to get to know a nice chunk of the staff, students, and faculty; being an open campus there are a lot of friendly people around with their dogs on the green, alumni, affiliates, and tourists. Good benefits and a few years ago HR began scaling up pay to be competitive with other smaller, private Universities. In the city/close to downtown.
cons: Having an open campus also means some crazies get on campus from time to time. Public Safety/Security are good about responding quickly and effectively though.

pros: A very helpful position that allowed me to take on responsibilities that will help in future jobs. These include communicating with other areas on campus, managing other employees, and opening/closing the facility.
cons: Maybe this was my experience, but because I have held other jobs in the past, this position was very easy. For others who have not had previous work experience, this is a good start to be promoted into.

pros: Diverse work environment with a vibrant and engaged student population. Good benefits package and friendly colleagues. Library and sports facilities are great resources.
cons: Top heavy institution with a detached and clinically minded senior management culture. Institutional IT and support departments are ineffective, self-centered and largely unhelpful to the staff and student populations they serve.

job_title: Clinical Assistant Professor in Seattle, WA
pros: Some of the best reasons to work at Seattle University are the faculty support services, the natural beauty of campus, and the numerous opportunities for faculty development on campus.
cons: For being in Seattle (the perception being the Seattle is forward thinking and ahead of the curve), the university is not alone in falling behind in certain aspects of global processes, such as university assessment processes, and an overall lack of standardization across the university. This is not entirely a detriment but for some people this would not be a pleasurable working experience if they crave standardization.

review_title: Avoid IT Services at all costs!
pros:
* Every interaction I have had with Seattle University in my time here outside of my own organization has been positive.

* Work-life balance is great if your direct report respects it

* Lots of time off, tuition reimbursement is a huge perk.

* Staff and faculty really do take their educational mission and commitment to diversity (as opposed to just wielding it as a buzzword, I've very rarely seen an environment where all are truly offered a voice and a seat at the table) seriously.

* If you like opportunities for volunteer work and community outreach, there are plenty for you here.
cons:
* This is mainly targeted at my own organization. Sorry. IT Services is a disaster full of leadership with no management skills or training, management that refuses to take responsibility for issues that arise from decisions made at a higher level. People at the director level and below that seem to be more concerned with appeasing people with titles than actually executing service improvements that align with our stated goals.

* Project management that refuses to get out of its own way and seems to only be concerned with project elements as line items that have to be powered through, and don't have the vision to look at things in a holistic manner. Project management that refuses to account for necessary resources. Project management that does not know how to plan.

* An alarming abundance of micromanagement as well as as a lack of respect for employees' time.

*  A key cultural behavior here: scheduling multiple people for hour-long meetings to address issues that require maybe 5-10 minutes of focus from individual contributors. Many of these meetings could just be replaced with an email.

* Pay/compensation are well below market rate but it's a non-profit and the educational sector so I'm not sure what to expect here.

* Certain employees have carved out little fiefdoms and partake in inappropriate behavior that has been reported to upper management and HR, yet the behavior persists.

review_title: Wonderful place to work and grow at.
pros: Great work/life balance, stable hours, friendly staff, and supportive administration. Plus lots of perks from working at a university (classes, gym, pool, benefits, retirement, generous vacation and sick leave). Plus at the end of the day you feel like you are making the world a better place.
cons: Universities in general pay below the standard for the same type of position in another industry. However, there are far less chances of overtime. College enrollment is going down and as a result departments are getting slimmer.

review_title: Writing Center-- positive environment for a student
pros: Working at the Writing Center has been extremely helpful for me to grow as a professional student. It's taught me how to handle deadlines, prioritize, and react in stressful situations.
cons: The writing center's scheduling method can sometimes be stressful (its an Excel document) and would be easier streamlined if we had an online scheduler (but its something that everyone's working on.)

review_title: Awesome people, benefits... not much compensation
pros:
The people are great! - students, employees, and the community
Awesome benefits package
Flexible schedule (depending on job)
Good location
Opened minded people
cons:
The salary is low
There is not much room for advancement or growth
It's hard to not feel like I'm in a dead end job. Not that it's a bad thing... I love what i do here, but i don't want to do it forever
Some people are very resistant to change

review_title: I like working at Seattle U and like my team.  Overall it's a great employer with fairly good benefits but lousy pay.
pros: SU is a mission-oriented organization dedicated to "educating leaders for a just and humane world."  Most faculty / staff live the mission and contribute positively to educate the next generation of leaders.  Longevity for many faculty / staff is a good indicator.
cons: Pay for many faculty, all adjuncts and most staff is sub-par.  You might have to wait for somebody to retire or die before you can advance your career.

review_title: Tuition Remission-Best Thing About The Job
pros: Overall campus community was great. Benefits are great, lots of time off. Lots of professional development opportunities. Tuition remission makes it all worth it. Students are amazing.
cons:
Below average pay. 
Top management heavy. 
No career ladder. 
I'm surprised they haven't been sued. Their HR office is horrendous. Management & HR shove a lot of things under the rug causing an uncomfortable and unproductive work environment. Little accountability for people who behave unprofessionally and unethically.

review_title: Great benefits, but salaries are low
pros: Subsidized ORCA card. 403(b) with employer contribution after the first year. Several health insurance options, including HSA and PPO plans. Tuition reimbursement. Lots of focus on social justice issues & opportunities to volunteer. Three paid days per year for volunteer activities, in addition to PTO.
cons: Low salaries/wages, so many employees have to live outside the city limits (long commutes). Hard for staff to move up the ladder, because the university is just as likely to hire from outside as they are to promote internal candidates.

review_title: Lots of work good work to be done, nice people, but clueless management
pros: Seattle U is a great working environment from the stance of there is a lot of work that needs and is desired to be done.  Tons of nice folks that mean well.
cons: They are so far behind on technology and planning, that they loose students and hire the wrong people.

pros: Good people who are focused on making the university and department a great place for students and scholars alike. Enjoyed working there. Campus is great and easy to get around. Technology in the classroom is overall good and easy to work with, though adding new tools can be tough (see cons).
cons: The usual issues with the bureaucracy of a university, higher-education institution apply. Some folks are far ahead with technology but quickly and easily doing new things with technology is still somewhat difficult.

review_title: Great work environment, slightly too driven by unreachable expectations.
job_title: "Director de análisis, innovación y transformación de RR. HH." in Seattle, WA
pros: Great time-off. Always had Christmas week-NYE off. The values were great, very mission based and prioritized students and social justice.
cons: Lots of coworkers were lazy and slow workers. Or maybe just inefficient. Change and progress need to be promoted more.

pros: Strong educational values as well as staff and faculty who know their material.  Even as a graduate student working as a tutor, the professors were approachable and caring.
cons: As you can imagine, pay is not that great.  Few universities and colleges pay well unless you are a professor in a tenure track position.

pros: If you like to work for an organization that helps you remember the vision and mission statement on a daily basis, this is the organization/institution for you.  Great educational benefits for employees and their families.  Good work-life balance.
cons: Limited promotional opportunities and no succession planning process to keep good employees in the institution.

pros: Seattle University is amazingly peaceful and serene.  There is a quiet intensity about this institution.  The students are focused, hardworking, and driven.
cons: I have very few cons to express.  The salary range is good if you are working as an adjunct faculty member and you have benefits from another institution.

review_title: Tutoring Services at Seattle University for Economics Classes
pros: The pros were basically that you got to frequently work with people. In addition, you really got to understand their problems and help them with preparation in addition to the course material provided.
cons: The cons were that the hours were not many. Mostly worked between 5-10 hours a week. In addition, many times the person getting tutored would not show up and you would not be compensated for your time.

pros: My boss was very understanding of situations and would back our decisions if complaints arose from the students.
cons: The filtering process was not very strict, as it was mainly a "first come first serve" for who got the position. Because of that, there were both too many people, and a few people who were very unqualified to help others.

pros:
--  Wonderful community of professionals committed to the mission of the university.
--  Great work/life balance
--  Nice work environment (physically)
--  Great benefits
cons: The only thing that would make my job here better is private-sector wages but the choice to work and be part of an organization that I'm proud of and whose mission I believe in strongly versus working the tech industry and making a lot more money is a no-brainer for me.

pros: Outstanding mission, beautiful campus in a couldn't-be-better location, lots of people who believe in their work and love what they do. Excellent benefits, including tuition.
cons: Woeful pay and precious little room for advancement and/or professional growth. A few administrators make terrifically inflated salaries while FT staff scramble in an expensive market to make ends meet.

pros: Seattle University provided some great values to their staff and great benefits to its full time employees. Jesuit Education was instilled in all work, but was transferable even if you don't identify as catholic.
cons: Leadership is very different from a public institution and can be very political. There are some issues of staff working beyond the job description leading to burnout.

review_title: Good for students with excellent supervisors.
pros: Students get a great opportunity to learn various skills at different jobs with excellent supervisors. TA positions are very guided and really fun.
cons: Hours are generally limited to less than part time for a single job. If you're grading, the "suggested hours" are often much less than the actual hours if you're focusing on the assignments.

review_title: Great employer, somewhat boring work - Student Worker
pros:
Solid community
Flexible hours (for a student like me)
Fair pay
Direct deposits 
No micromanaging
Very easy work
Great people!
cons:
Little to no progression
No extra skills training beyond the initial "here's how to do the job" 
Management protects us from projects from other office managers

review_title: Great positive environment in Conference and Events!
pros: Amazing benefits, great hours, mission driven, and best of all great people to work with! Great energy in Conference and Events one of the best departments to work in!
cons: I can't think of any they really do support you as an employee on all playing fields!

pros: Great health benefits and tuition remission. The community is welcoming.
cons: Extremely low pay with no upward mobility. It is impossible to get a promotion unless someone retires or leaves. People are afraid of change. Also, professors often look down at staff because staff don’t have a ph.d like them.

pros: make your own hours, talented staff, understanding PI, very central location to the seattle area, nice to work on campus.
cons: It is a very small university, so you don't have access to a lot of the same funding and resources as other big institutions.

job_title: Senior Executive Coordinator in Seattle, WA
pros: Great benefits and extra holidays off; friendly people who care about the University.
cons: Like all Universities nowadays, lack of sufficent compensation for most employees due to Seattle's rising living cost.

job_title: Web Migration Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros: I enjoyed the freedom and creativity that was fostered while working here. The people are really nice and want to help you succeed.
cons: The compensation was not very impressive mainly because it's an on campus job. Also, sometimes it was tough to get a hold of certain people that I needed to complete certain tasks.

pros: Great bosses. But that was a result of my department. Conference and Event Services is one of the few departments that are efficiently and effectively run.
cons: Few. Just the normal paperwork, trainings, and other shenanigans that come with working for a large institution.

job_title: Lead Accounting Tutor in Des Moines, WA
pros: Student job where you gain experience helping others understand technical accounting issues.  Also great networking opportunities with working professionals who needs refreshers.
cons: The pay isn't amazing, especially given our skill set, and hours available are minimized, some work is menial in nature.

review_title: Great benefits & culture, low pay, still worth it.
job_title: Finance Operations Manager in Seattle, WA
pros: Excellent culture, work life balance, lovely campus, amazing benefits (10% retirement, free tuition)
cons: Pay is roughly 10-20% below market for the area. Leadership disconnected from the mission. Lowest level staff continue to be underpaid and  overloaded with work. Academic bureaucracy make change nearly impossible.

pros:
-Good pay
-Knew school was important and allowed for flexible scheduling around exams 
- Good management
- Cared about employees
cons:
- I worked in a manual labor job which could be especially rough in the summer or when we were low on employees
- Bad hours (I worked as late as 1 am on a Saturday night)

pros: The best reason I stayed so long was the people.  Also the benefits were extremely good.  Free tuition for your dependence, health insurance, vacation and time off, and working environment.
cons: There wasn't much down side too working there the only thing that happened was that they illuminated my job after 32 years.

pros: Everyone is really respectful and supportive on new ideas. Great opportunity to get involved in Student affairs. Constant changes are made to improve quality services for students and staff
cons: Lots of changes are being made, so processes might take longer that expected. However, people are normally welcoming and will do their best

pros: Flexible hours to accommodate studying and a wonderful environment to work at (Facilities)
cons: There really ain't any if you work with the Electrical Shop. Grounds has a bunch of tough requirements and minimum hours but Electrical Shop is cool.

review_title: Great community of people, slower decision making process, lower pay, amazing reward.
job_title: Event & Operations Supervisor in Seattle, WA
pros:
+ Great campus
+ Wonderful people
+ Great benefits and holiday schedule
+ New office systems furniture
cons:
- Slow decision making process (most everything is consensus based)
- Interesting use of school funds at times...seems wasteful in some areas...
- Lower average market pay

pros: Flexibility with hours is a pro, in addition to benefits if you are attending to school in Seattle U.
cons: The salaries for work-study positions are capped. Tuition benefits are not offered for work-study roles.

pros: Some tuition paid for by the employer, lots of paid holidays, fairly flexible hours
cons: Significantly under-market salaries, terrible benefits, high maintenance staff and faculty

review_title: A wonderful community to work in that is dedicated to their mission.
pros: Excellent benefits, Wonderful work-life balance, community is deeply committed to the mission of the university, and deeply committed to eachother.
cons: In non-faculty jobs, one must adjust to the "non-profit discount" as far as pay is concerned.

review_title: Great mission, nice students, good balance of research and teaching.
pros: Good balance of teaching and research expectations, focused students, dedication to service learning.
cons: Limited research resources (but getting better), low salary (but no one goes into academia to make money and the pay is comparable to other similar institutions).

pros: The people. Tuition reimbursement for your family is huge!
cons: The salary is terrible. The salaries are below market range. Once you no longer need the tuition, you won't need the job as well....sad because it's a very nice place to work.

job_title: Community Collegium Leader in Seattle, WA
pros: flexible schedules, raising minimum wage, fun position
cons: Luck of the draw with supervisors. I had a great supervisor which made work easy and fun.

pros: Spanish department as great professors who are willing to help.
cons: It's tough to receive more than two courses per quarter as an adjunct. School does not want to pay teachers much. It also places higher importance on sports over academics.

review_title: Seattle University is a great organization to work for. They jobs that they provide can help you prepare for the future.
pros: They are caring and respect their employees. Seattle University is a great organization to work for.
cons: I had know issues working at seattle university.

review_title: Excellent!  Great environment!  The Higher Education environment is very positive and rewarding
job_title: Corporate Relations Manager in Seattle, WA
pros:
Helping Students is rewarding
Students are Enthusiastic
Faculty Are Very Smart and Talented
cons: Pay is above traditional nonprofit organizations but of course below the corporate world

pros: Flexible schedule and instructing Graduate students
cons: Temporary Position and No benefits for Temporary Workers

job_title: Work Study/Student Gardener in Seattle, WA
pros: Patient supervisors, flexible scheduling, easy hiring process
cons: It'd be great if they could provide a pre-loaded Orca or Orca Lift card for employees

review_title: Good values but not a place for urgency or change
pros:
Excellent mission
Many nurturing HR policies
cons: Like many universities, there is a distinct separation of faculty and staff.

job_title: AP Student Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros:
Wonderful people and you get to learn a lot.
They also have free snacks/candy (which is amazing)
cons: No cons really. It's a good stepping stone for a student looking to become a professional.

job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros: Great Faculty, staff and students with easy schedule and supportive co-workers.
cons: Some Faculty can be difficult to work around.

job_title: Collegium Community Leader in Seattle, WA
pros: Great people to work with. A lot of room to grow.
cons: Once you are done with school it is very difficult to get back in as a full time employee.

pros: Fun work environment, most people are great to work with as well.
cons: Very old office and old computer software.

pros: I enjoy the academic Flexibility, Friendly, and Freedom
cons: Academic positions pay is less than industry

job_title: Student Office Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros:
You'll get to meet and work with many passionate peers who actually care for their clients/students
Warm and conducive environment
cons: Nothing I can think of

pros:
Plenty of time to study
Relatively slow office, can catch up on Netflix from time to time
cons: Can be boring at times

pros: Good pay, engaged colleagues, and the size means ease of speaking to higher-ups.
cons: Transparency with upper administration could use some work, this is more a university-wide problem

pros: Diverse staff, Variety of networking opportunities. New commitment to data driven metrics.
cons: Passive-aggressive administrative culture, little follow-through on "cultural issues." commitment to data driven metrics is new.

job_title: Digital Media Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros: Loved the staff and the overall support system. Dedicated to helping you learn.
cons: Need to be able to take initiative and teach yourself some new skills.

review_title: Great professors to work with during the summer.
pros: flexible hours. good pay. great colleagues.
cons: no specific cons other than the requirements after doing the research (e.g. give talks)

pros: Small and get to know your co-workers
cons: Entry level lower paying job, but it was a time when I had just graduated college.

pros: It is very easy to get an A in any class if you put minimal effort.
cons: Too easy. But you get what you put in.

pros: Great benefits and good pay. Opportunities beyond job title if interested. Great Manager
cons: Lack of understanding and use of technology in some work groups.

pros: Defined tasks. No micro-management. Nice campus and location. You can work and study, that's a plus.
cons: Limited oppurtunities. Compensation is not great.

job_title: Student Help Desk Technician in Seattle, WA
pros: Works well with your schedule, and is on campus
cons: Difficult to get promoted as a student employee

pros: Friendly people, easy work, flexible scheduling.
cons: Limited to 16-20 hours per week.

pros: Great school with a lot of hidden opportunities. You have to find them!
cons: Since school is small, don't have a lot of classes

job_title: Shipping and Receiving in Seattle, WA
pros: Good employees working in this place
cons: Terrible management and the benefits are not good enough

pros: great benefits, depending on the department- great people

review_title: Document Delivery Center Student Assistant Review
pros: Great work environment, plenty of opportunities to work on your studies during down-time.

review_title: Working as a part time  graduate assistant

pros: Flexible hours, lots of time to do homework

pros: They had a good environment with a lot of inner department support.

review_title: Great mission, pay just isn't there

review_title: It was an unforgettable experience studying at Seattle University
pros: Good pay and very diverse community.
cons: Lack of training and uncertainty.

job_title: Classroom Tech Support in Seattle, WA
pros: Team work, Good learning environemnt
cons: No cons as such that creates a bad working environment.

review_title: Everyone is extremely nice in my department

pros: Great platform to learn and work

pros: Good pay, easy workload, flexible hrs

pros: Great culture, benefits, and work-life balance.

pros: Large pay, good school, great employees
